entry.title: Using Different ATP Checking Rules for Planned Orders and Process Orders in SAP S/4HANA PP
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am working on SAP S/4HANA (Standard) in Production Planning ‚Äì Process Industry (PP-PI) and I have the following two requirements related to Availability Check:

  1. Planned Orders (after MRP run):
    Once MRP is executed and planned orders are generated, I want to run an availability check to verify whether the required components are available in the plant, in order to validate the feasibility of planned orders before conversion.

  2. Process Orders (after conversion):
    After converting the planned order to a process order, I want to run another availability check to verify whether the components have already been staged / transferred to the production storage location.

From my understanding:

  • In MRP Customizing (OPPQ), the checking rule for ATP in planned orders is assigned (default = PP).

  • In OPJK, the checking rule for process orders is also assigned (default = PP).

  • Regardless of the checking rule, the components are still assigned to a single Availability Check Control (e.g. 02 / CH) at material level.

This leads me to the following questions:

  • Is it acceptable / recommended to separate the checking rules for planned orders and process orders (e.g. PP for process orders and a custom rule like PP2 for planned orders)?

  • Is there a standard SAP checking rule intended for this scenario, or is creating a custom rule the correct approach?

  • How do you typically differentiate between:

    • a feasibility check at planned order level, and

    • a staging/transfer validation at process order level,
      given that the same availability check control is used?

My goal is:

  • To use availability check on planned orders to validate feasibility before conversion.

  • To use availability check on process orders to confirm whether material staging has been completed.

Any guidance on best practice or standard SAP behavior would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance.

entry.title: Re: ABAP Extensibility Guide ‚Äì Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - August 2025 Update
entry.content:
Hi @OlgaDolinskaja ,

I came across this blog of you when looking for some proof to indicate that SQV* queries are not considered clean core.
So far I found nothing clearly stating that this is the case, even though I am fully aware that the use of those queries is far from clean core simply because they use tables directly and generate classic programs, both of these are not considered clean core.

As alternatives I can think of the following options:

1. Using Standard Apps or Reports
Using standard objects is always preferred. 

2. Custom CDS Views App
https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1866A')/S31PCE 
This allows for the creation of CDS views without writing code, though some limitations apply.
The most significant limitation is likely that only released views can be used; however, this immediately ensures the solution is Cloud Ready.

3. Building a Custom (RAP-based) CDS Report
This option removes the restrictions found in the first two options.
The developer can create a report exactly as requested.
Development must still adhere to best practices and guidelines.

I would love to get your insights and ideas on this.
Thanks a lot.

Kind Regards,
Joery

entry.title: The Secret Shopper for SAP Agents: Why Enterprise AI Needs a Reality Check with Int4 Suite
entry.content:
The enterprise software world is currently ‚Äúa bit‚Äù obsessed with "Agentic AI". We‚Äôre moving away from rigid, click-here-then-there workflows toward SAP Joule agents, autonomous entities that can reason, use tools, and execute complex business processes like the ones show in the figure below: 

Figure 1 - SAP Joule Agents 

But as we hand the keys of our SAP S/4HANA systems over to these digital coworkers, we face a fundamental crisis: The Death of Determinism. For decades, software testing followed a simple rule: Input X + Logic F = Output Y. It was predictable. With AI agents, that‚Äôs gone. An agent might solve the same problem three different ways on three different days. This creates a "Verification Gap" where traditional testing fails. If your AI agent "hallucinates" a successful transaction that never actually hits the database, your supply chain doesn't just slow down, it breaks. Here is why your enterprise needs a new way to test, and how Int4 Suite is stepping in as an Enterprise AI validator or in some business scenarios as a "Secret Shopper" for the AI era.

The Hallucination Trap: Why "Polite" AI Isn't Enough for Enterprise AI 

Most AI testing tools today are Guardrail Platforms. They are like bouncers at a club: they make sure the AI doesn't say anything offensive, leak a credit card number, or succumb to a prompt injection attack.

While essential for security, these tools have a massive blind spot: Functional Integrity. If SAP Joule Agents tells you, "I‚Äôve processed that sales order for you!" with a polite digital smile, but it actually failed to map the tax jurisdiction code correctly in SAP S/4HANA, the "security" tools won't catch it. They validate the Tool Call (what the agent intended to do), but they don't validate the Tool Execution (what actually happened in the database).

The "Secret Shopper" Scenario: Order-to-Cash

Imagine you want to check the quality of service at a high-end retail store. You don't just ask the manager if the staff is good; you send in a Secret Shopper, a person with a specific script who tests the system's limits and reports back on exactly what happened.

In the world of SAP S/4HANA, Int4 Suite acts as that Secret Shopper for the Order-to-Cash (O2C) process. Here‚Äôs how the "Mission" looks:

  1. The Trigger: A customer sends an email with an attached PDF order.

  2. The Agent's Job: SAP Joule (the AI agent) must read the email, parse the PDF, and autonomously create a Sales Order, an Outbound Delivery, and an Invoice in SAP S/4HANA.

Figure 2 - Order to Cash process started by a PDF inside an e-mail, processed by the AI Agent completely 

  1. The Int4 Suite "Mission":

  • Fetch & Fabricate: Int4 Suite fetches a real historical email and PDF from your system using its Robotic Crawler. It then dynamically changes the values (unique qualifier like the Order reference, etc.) so the test is unique and won't clash with existing data.

  • The Sting: Int4 Suite resends this unique "mystery" order to the AI agent.

  • The Deep Audit: This is where Int4 Suite shines. While other tools just watch the "chat," Int4 Suite goes into the SAP S/4HANA backend. It validates the resulting documents up to the field level.

Figure 3 - Replication of the original process by this time completely run by Int4 Suite and validated in the SAP S/4HANA DB. 

Did the agent correctly calculate the net value? Is the shipping point correct? Did the invoice trigger the right accounting document? Int4 Suite compares the agent's work against historical "gold standard" documents to ensure 100% accuracy.

Figure 4 - SAP S/4HANA DB validation of a sales order posting 

The FWE Model: A New Standard for AI Validation

To truly trust an AI agent, you need a Functional Workflow Execution (FWE) model. This is the architectural loop that Int4 Suite has perfected:

  • Technical Flow Implementation: Setting up the "harness" where the agent lives.

  • Test Case Definition: Defining what "success" actually looks like - Order posted with a certain number of lines, Delivery posted with certain quantities, etc..

Figure 5 - Test Workflow definition inside Int4 Suite 

  • Dynamic Data Fabrication: Using the Robotic Crawler to mine historical messages and "seed" the test environment with valid, complex data.

  • Agent Execution: Letting the AI run wild in a deterministic "sandbox."

  • Backend Validation: Programmatically inspecting SAP S/4HANA database entries, IDocs, and API responses to verify the "side effects" of the AI‚Äôs actions.

Why Int4 Suite‚Äôs approach is Unique? 

While the market is flooded with "AI Security" startups, they lack the "plumbing" to talk to SAP. Int4 Suite was born in the world of SAP integration (PI/PO, CPI). It speaks the language of IDocs, OData, APIs in general.

We are witnessing a shift from deterministic chains to probabilistic agents. You can't test a probabilistic agent with a spreadsheet and a prayer.

If you are deploying SAP Joule, you need a validator that doesn't just listen to what the agent says, but verifies what the agent did. By leveraging service virtualization and deep backend inspection, Int4 Suite ensures that your "Secret Shopper" tests don't just find hallucinations, they build a foundation of enterprise-grade trust.

Ready to send a Secret Shopper into your S/4HANA system? It‚Äôs time to move beyond the chat bubble and into the database.

Further Learning on Int4 Suite: Avoiding Project Delays

If you want to dive deeper into how to decouple your project timeline from external risks, SAP provides a dedicated learning path on this exact topic.

  • SAP Learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

entry.title: Re: Packaging Instruction Determination Not Triggering Di...
entry.content:
Hello @vicentejarque

Thank you for your question

What you configured in Maintain Packing Transaction Profile is valid configuration but the behaviour you expect typically does not appear in the Fiori process. The reason is that the packing execution in these apps is based on Unified Package Building and in that framework the Packing Instruction Selection Dialog parameter is not evaluated.  See Unified Package Building Profile for more details.

That is why you see automatic determination but no user choice dialog, even when alternative packing instructions exist.

Important consideration to note, VL31N is an SAP GUI transaction. The public cloud expects you to use the Fiori inbound delivery apps. The relevant packing execution is the packing work center launched from Change Inbound Deliveries. Your observation in the Fiori app is the one that matters for public cloud behaviour.

In public cloud it is possible to use packing instruction determination to automatically create HU proposals, use alternative packing instructions but only as part of automatic logic and maintain records with the condition technique so the system selects the correct packing instruction. See Packing Instruction Determination and HUM - Determination record for packing instruction for more insights.

However, you cannot manually select dialog for choosing between multiple valid packing instructions during automatic expansion. The selection dialog setting in the packing transaction profile is not taken into account in UPB based packing.

So, you are not missing an SSCUI step. It seems you are facing a functional public cloud limitation of the packing execution framework. So, the question is, how do you model two valid options without relying on a user dialog.

My suggestion is to make the determination unambiguous. If the material can arrive in two different forms, you should make that difference explicit in your determination criteria so only one packing instruction is valid at a time. The public cloud offers you the options to:

  1. Use different determination keys based on business data that is available at inbound delivery level for example supplier, plant, ship to part, etc.
  2. If the difference is truly physical form A versus form B, you should consider using batch characteristics or a distinguishable product attribute that is available at the time of receipt, then you drive the determination with that.

Another option, if you truly need a warehouse operator choice when you execute, that requirement is more aligned with the EWM packaging specification handling than S4 packing instruction selection dialog expectations. In public cloud embedded EWM, many packing activities are executed in EWM style apps but the specific selection dialog flag you referenced is not the mechanism to achieve that in Fiori.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to Identify Source Tables and Fields for Legal Parameters in SAP HR Payroll
entry.content:
Hello,

As you know, there are many SAP standard tables where rates and parameters are maintained for payroll calculations. These values are later used in payroll schemas and rules to produce payroll results.

When a legal parameter changes, I would like to understand how I can identify from which table and which specific field the system is reading the data.
For example, tables such as T7TRG01, V_T7TRG02, V_T7TRT01, V_T7TRT02, V_T7TRT03, and similar ones.

My usual approach is to start from a wage type generated for a specific personnel number and then trace it backwards. During this process, I often end up at table T596F, but at that point I still cannot clearly identify which field or logic is used to calculate the wage type.

Is there an easier or more systematic way to analyze this?
If you have any known methods, best practices, or tips for tracing payroll calculations back to their source tables and fields, I would really appreciate your guidance.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Enes

entry.title: Integrating Cloud Application Lifecyle Management (CALM) with Trading Partner Management (TPM)
entry.content:
Introduction

I am happy to announce that SAP Cloud ALM can now be connected to Trading Partner Management, with which you can configure automated alerting based on B2B scenario-specific details, like trading partners, type systems, message types, etc.
Building a seamless End-To-End monitoring experience closes the gap between IT and business. 
In this blog, we explore how unifying CALM and TPM streamlines operations and helps teams detect issues earlier - before they impact critical business processes. 

The integration between SAP Cloud ALM and SAP Cloud services like SAP Integration Suite (Trading Partner Management) is orchestrated by SAP-Managed Connectivity, which already provides an automated connectivity setup for all your tenants.
All you need to do is to activate the TPM integration, so that the data is sent from TPM to CALM.
In addition, you need to turn on the data collection, so that CALM continuously (every 5 minutes) pulls data (every interchange) from TPM's B2B Monitoring. This is a one-time activity.
*In CALM it is called the push job because data is pushed from TPM to CALM.*
The alert notification configurations are done on CALM side.  


Setup steps in SAP Cloud ALM

Activation

Go to CALM --> Operations --> Integration & Exception Monitoring 

*Note: Health Monitoring will not be available in CALM for Trading Partner Management. The certificate alert in the Trading Partner Profiles (TPP) will be implemented within TPM itself. In the TPM UI, you will see which certificates are about to expire soon and are already expired. 

Go to Select a Scope --> Select all relevant Services, particularly SAP Integration Suite (Trading Partner Management) --> Go --> Apply

You will now see the scope based on your settings. 
Go to Configuration --> Services/Systems --> Activate the service

*Note: For the initial enablement, it could take up to 24 hours for the data to start appearing.
Once you see the messages, you are connected to TPM:

Note: In the screenshot above you see the messages from January 12 00:00am to January 12 4:04pm. You can adjust the time frame accordingly. Further you see that in this time frame there is one failed interchange and in total three open alerts that are still to be investigated by operations team (Alerts and E-Mail notification were already maintained in this case). 
You can also click on the Messages Hyperlink to view the messages and see the relevant metadata in detail.
Currently, only failed or unassigned interchanges are marked in red in CALM.

Notification Management

If you plan to automatically trigger alerts via e-mail, you have to maintain the users or distribution lists inside of CALM.

Note: CALM will unify Notification Management with User Management to simplify your tasks. The dedicated management of recipients in Notification Management will soon be deprecated.
Hence, all users in User Management app can receive notifications.
You can create external users or distribution lists as users in the User Management without assigning them any roles.

In the future Go to CALM --> Administration --> User Management

 

As long as it is still not migrated to the new approach
Go to CALM --> Notification Management

Note: Once you have added the recipients, they will receive a notification and must give the consent. Once this is done the status will switch from Pending to Verified. The validity period for users is six months, after which it must be extended.

 Configuration - Event Settings

Now we have to define the parameters for the Event actions. 
Go to Edit Configuration

Go to Events --> Add

*Note: The following will give a proposal on how the configuration could look like.
Choose the Event Name: Issues detected in SAP Trading Partner Management and define the parameter values, so that one event per calculation is sufficient - meaning that if a single interchange is detected, it will be registered as soon as the message is older than 1 minute:

As mentioned in the beginning the most critical interchanges are the failed and unassigned ones. That is why we will filter particularly for them:


Now we need to define the grouping parameters for the event.
Basically, the alerts or the e-mail body will contain the Object Details with all these attributes filled with their values of the corresponding interchange, such as for example Direction = OUTBOUND | Receiver Document Standard = SAP_IDoc | Sender Message Type = 850, etc. 

This is then how an example alert looks like in CALM:

 

Now coming to the last step on how the event action should look like. In this case we do want to see the alerts in CALM and additionally send email to the specific group:

Save the configuration settings and you are done. 
Note: There is also the possibility to connect CALM to external ticket systems, such as ServiceNow to create incidents. There is also the possibility that CALM can forward the exceptions to chat tools, such as MS Teams to create messages in chat channels. 
This is not covered in this blog.

Analysis of E-Mail Alerts

The E-Mail will contain the Object Details shown above (For unassigned interfaces, there won't be any attribute, except for the Message ID) and additional information with the Message ID (each interchange has a unique ID), the Status text, from which you could derive already what kind of issue it is and the timestamp (caution: CALM uses UTC, while B2B Monitoring uses the user's local timezone):

Interchange Transmission Failed always refer to that the target message could not be send to the receiving system, due to e.g. unavailability of the system. 
You can click on the hyperlink to view the alert in CALM. Monitoring in CALM will be shown in the next section.
I want to show how this message can be easily found in B2B Monitoring using the Message ID:

*Note: Once the system is available, you can use the retry mechanism of B2B Monitoring

In the same way, you can search for unassigned messages and view the error details:


Nice to know

Before we jump into the Monitoring in CALM, there is one more additional feature that you should know. It might be the case that the user wants to preferably monitor the interchanges in CALM using unique business document identifiers, such as e.g. the Purchase Order number or the Invoice number.
CALM's Monitoring dashboard supports an additional search field (next to the Message ID), which is the Document ID.
In TPM, we use the same terminology, which needs to be defined as Custom Search Attribute:

Now in each business transaction activity, you can define the value of the Document ID (usually via XPath). 
If you want to log the IDoc Number for messages that are send via IDoc Receiver Adapter, use the Source Type Parameter and the value SAP_TPM_IDocNumber:

This provides complete traceability across the whole process.


Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM

As you saw in the mail, you can view the alert in CALM. If you click on the hyperlink you will be redirected to CALM's alert dashboard:

You can click on the Message ID and can see further details, such as the B2B Monitoring URL and a more detailed error description:

If you want to see all messages, click on the Messages Hyperlink in the Integration & Exception Monitoring Dashboard:

 

You will see some charts about the total number of messages by e.g. Receiver Name, Sender Name, Sender Message Type, etc. 
You can apply the filter to search for messages based on a unique business document identifier:

 


Share your thoughts

I'd love to hear what you think about the current solution.
Your feedback will help to get further valuable perspectives on how automated alerting could be optimized.

entry.title: Re: BADI/Function Module for Variant Configuration in Sal...
entry.content:
Dear @s_sudhirkumar,

In Private Cloud the Import Sales Orders using Files app (F4293) is backed by the Sales Document Import from Spreadsheet framework and as delivered, it does not reliably support configurable materials / VC. SAP has an explicit Note describing the symptom when you try to import a sales order for a configurable material the sales order item is created without characteristic values or the order is not created at all

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003198686

Best-practice recommendation for Private Edition, if you need this to be robust and upgrade-tolerant:

1. Do not enhance the delivered SAPUI5/Fiori app (F4293) directly to handle VC payload. You will be coupling yourself to SAP internal import job structures and upgrade cycles and you still need a backend VC-capable creation interface

2. Build a custom mass-upload service ABAP/RAP or classic that:

    • reads the spreadsheet
    • maps columns to characteristic/value assignments
    • calls BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2 with the ORDER_CFGS_* tables filled or sends ORDERS05 if you choose IDoc
    • returns an application log comparable to F4293

More details below:

https://api.sap.com/package/eu10.storecontentdev.creationofsalesorderbapi5/overview

This gives you clean control over:

  • validation mandatory characteristics, allowed values
  • performance batching/commit strategy
  • error handling and replay
  • future VC changes new characteristics, multi-value characteristics

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Error message when trying to access "My Products Packages" for SAP BDC
entry.content:
**Updated January 2026**

Symptom: You see the following message when you go to "Portfolio & Products" section from Dashboards in SAP for Me to get access to the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) card: "No authorization. You are missing authorizations for your eligible product packages. Make sure that you have either Display Cloud Data or Edit Cloud Data authorization for the installation number of each product package."

Requirements:

  • You need to be a Super Admin in SAP for Me OR
  • You need to be a  Cloud Admin. If you're a Cloud Admin, make sure you are assigned as well to the BDC installation you want to provide access to. 

Resolution: A) Find out your installation name and number and B) Proceed with the authorization task. 

A) Find out your installation name and number:

1. Open this link ("Business Data Cloud" page in "Portfolio & Products"). 

2. Click on the line "SAP Business Data Cloud". 

3. Go to "Systems" tab and check the second column, "Installation". There is an installation name and number. In this example, the installation name is "SAP Cloud Generic", and the installation number starts with 9.

4. Save this installation name and number for the next step. 

Image 01

Image 02

 

B) Proceed with the authorization task:

1. Open this link ("S-User Management" page from SAP for Me).

2. Search for the user name you want to provide access to.

3. Click on the user line.

4. Go to the "Authorizations" section, then click to edit it.

5. Go to "Cloud" section and check the boxes for both options, "Display Cloud Data" and "Edit Cloud Data".

6. Open the installations and make sure you are assigned to the one related to BDC. In this example, the user doesn't have the installation attached. 

7. Click on the "+" sign.

8. Select the installation name and number from SAP BDC, then click "Ok". 

9. Goo back to the authorizations page, scroll up to the title "Authorizations", and click "Save". 

10. A pop up will appear: "Authorizations were updated successfully". 

 

Image 01

Image 02

Image 03

Image 04

Image 05

Image 06

Image 07

Sources:

  •  About the User, Authorization and Administrator Concept

entry.title: Depreciation time is shortened after changing asset master
entry.content:
I executed test scenario as below:

AUC Creation
  • Step 1: KO01„ÉºCreate Internal Order
  • Step 2: FV60 ‚Äì Post vendor invoice
  • Step 3: KO88 ‚Äì Settlement
Final Asset Transfer
  • Step 4: AS01 ‚Äì Create final asset
  • Step 5: KO02 ‚Äì Maintain Settlement Rule (Assign Final Asset Number)
  • Step 6: KO88 ‚Äì Settlement (AUC ‚Üí Final Asset)
  • Step 7: AS03 ‚Äì Display Asset
  • Step 8: AW01NÔºçDisplay Asset Explorer
Asset Impairment
  • Step 9: ABAWL„ÉºTransfer Impairment Amount to Asset
  • Step 10: AS02„ÉºChange Asset Master Data

           Maintain country-specific impairment data in asset master

           Create a new time-dependent interval in the depreciation area using new depreciation parameters
            Refer to SAP Note 951312
  • Step 11: AFAB„ÉºPosting of impairment amount to asset
  • Step 12: AW01NÔºçDisplay Asset Explorer (Compairisons Tab)

After checking planned depreciation in AW01N, I found that the base value used to calculate planned depreciation does not deduct the impairment amount. As a result, the annual depreciation amount is calculated higher than it should be, causing depreciation to be completed earlier than planned. 

Do you know the reason why it is like that? 

Is there anything special about assets transferred from AuC? Because when I tested with an asset acquired directly via T-code ABZON, this issue did not occur.

For more information, refer the images below

Depreciation before impairment

Step 8: AW01NÔºçDisplay Asset Explorer

Depreciation time is from 2025 to 2040

Asset Impairment

Step 10: AS02„ÄÄ„ÉºChange Asset Master Data

 

Step 12: AW01NÔºçDisplay Asset Explorer 

Depreciation time is shortened, from 2025 to 2033 instead of 2025 to 2040 as above.

entry.title: SAP MDG Service Mapping Tools (SMT)
entry.content:
SAP MDG Service Mapping Tools (SMT)The service mapping tools (SMT) in SAP master data governance (MDG) is a framework use to define and manage data mapping between.

 

  1. Staging area structure
  2. Active area table
  3. Remote system or interface

Use :

  1. Replication or consolidation data between stating and active area.
  2. Map internal data structure to external system.
  3. Handle filed name or mismatches between system.

 

 Configuration path :

Master Data Governance -> Classic Mode in SAP MDG -> Central Governance -> General Settings -> Data Modeling -> Generate Data Model-Specific Structure

SMT Mapping from Active Area :  Active area to staging area

SMT Mapping to Active Area: Staging area to active area

  1. Creating New field in ZAB_LFA1 structure : Industry Key (BRSCH)

  1. Creating Mapping for new field i.e. Industry Key :

Path: SMT-> Transformation Workbench -> Create and Edit Mappings

 

  • Source Structure: ZAB_LFA1
     This is a custom structure you created in Step 1 for supplier master data.
  • Target Structure: LFA1
     This is the standard SAP Vendor Master Table in ECC/S4HANA.
  • Mapping Step: ZMAP_HEADER
    This defines how fields from ZAB_LFA1 map to fields in LFA1.
  1. Need to map field one by one Source system to Target system

 

  • Select Source Structure (ZAB_LFA1) and Target Structure (LFA1).
  • For each field:
    1. Click on the source field (e.g., SUPPLIER_NO).
    2. Click on the target field (e.g., LIFNR)
    3. Click Map.

Repeat for all fields listed above.

Save and activate the mapping.

  1. Need to check Mapping:

Path: Transformation Workbench -> Check Customizing

 

  • check the mapping in SAP MDG and ensure there are no errors, you need to use the Transformation Workbench. Here‚Äôs the proper procedure
  1. If need we can add logic for source system to target system: (custom program)

Create custom program we will use T code SE38 here we will use standard class by SAP  CL_SMT_ENGINE.

Constructor and Executor methods in the Transformation Workbench

  • Methods Constructor:

Following Parameter are use.

entry.title: Re: different e-mail adresses for sending purchase order...
entry.content:
Maintain one additional eMail-Address in the vendor master

"Mis"-use field remark to define the type of the address:

I use following remarks

  • BA ‚Ä¶ Bestelladresse
  • GS ‚Ä¶ Gutschrift an (ERS or Consignment Settlement) ‚Äì Must be defined as default address

LIV output types are always sent to the default mail address (hardcoded), therefore you have to change it for purchase order/contract/inquiry to send it to an other address

Implement BADI BADI_MM_PO_OC_EMAIL  ---- IF_BADI_MM_PO_OC_EMAIL~CHANGE_RECIPIENTS

      DATA lv_smtp_addr TYPE ad_smtpadr.
      SELECT SINGLE a~smtp_addr
         INTO lv_smtp_addr
         FROM adr6 AS a
              INNER JOIN adrt AS b ON a~addrnumber = b~addrnumber AND a~persnumber = b~persnumber AND a~date_from = b~date_from AND a~consnumber = b~consnumber
              INNER JOIN lfa1 AS c ON b~addrnumber = c~adrnr
        WHERE c~lifnr = im_nast_entry-parnr AND b~remark = 'BA' AND b~comm_type = 'INT'.
      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        CLEAR cht_to_recipient_list.
        APPEND lv_smtp_addr TO cht_to_recipient_list.
      ENDIF.

entry.title: Pix Automatic: How Brazil Is Redefining Recurring Payments ‚Äî and What This Means for SAP
entry.content:
Brazil‚Äôs Pix ecosystem continues to evolve at remarkable speed. After transforming instant payments, the Pix Automatic initiative marks a decisive step toward fully digital, API-driven recurring payments, challenging traditional direct debit models and opening new opportunities for ERP and SAP-based environments.

Pix Automatic is not just a new payment option. It represents a shift in how recurring financial processes are designed, authorized, and integrated.

What Is Pix Automatic?

Pix Automatic enables recurring payments through a single customer authorization, executed automatically on predefined dates, using the Pix infrastructure.

In practical terms, it combines:

  • The convenience of direct debit
  • The speed and availability of Pix
  • A modern, API-first architecture

Typical use cases include:

  • Utilities (energy, water, telecom)
  • Subscriptions and memberships
  • Education fees
  • Insurance and recurring services

Once authorized, payments occur automatically, within limits defined by the customer (amount, frequency, validity).

Why Pix Automatic Is a Game Changer

For customers

  • One-time digital authorization
  • Full control (limits, cancellation at any time)
  • No dependence on cards or legacy debit agreements

For companies

  • Reduced churn and late payments
  • Lower operational costs compared to boletos
  • Access to customers without credit cards
  • Real-time settlement and reconciliation

For banks and ERPs

  • API-based orchestration instead of file-based processing
  • Event-driven payment flows
  • Real-time visibility over execution and failures

The Impact on SAP Landscapes

Traditional recurring payment models in SAP often rely on:

  • Batch processing
  • File exchanges
  • Rigid bank-specific configurations

Pix Automatic changes this paradigm. In SAP environments (ECC or S/4HANA), Pix Automatic enables:

  • I-based payment initiation
  • Real-time payment status feedback
  • Immediate posting and reconciliation
  • Reduced dependency on classic payment files and bank formats

This evolution aligns naturally with:

  • Event-driven architectures
  • Clean Core principles
  • Cloud-first integration strategies

From Concept to Reality: Pilot Projects Matter

While the regulatory framework is defined by the Central Bank of Brazil, real innovation happens in pilot projects, where banks, technology partners, and customers test real-life scenarios.

A strong example applied to SAP is the Pix Automatic API pilot being developed by Santander Brazil in partnership with a SAP Consulting Company.

Why this pilot is relevant:

  • Focus on SAP-native integration
  • Direct consumption of Pix Automatic APIs
  • Real-time orchestration between SAP and bank systems
  • No reliance on traditional payment runs or file-based interfaces
  • Designed for scalability across multiple business scenarios

This type of initiative demonstrates that Pix Automatic is not theoretical ‚Äî it is enterprise-ready and already being shaped for mission-critical ERP processes.

A Strategic Perspective

Pix Automatic is more than a payment feature. It is a signal that:

  • Banking is becoming API-centric
  • ERP systems must be event-aware
  • Finance processes are moving from batch to continuous execution

For SAP customers, this means rethinking:

  • How recurring receivables are designed
  • How bank integration is architected
  • How finance operations can become more automated and resilient

Those who start experimenting now ‚Äî through pilots and controlled rollouts ‚Äî will be better positioned as Pix Automatic becomes mainstream.

Final Thoughts

Pix transformed instant payments. Pix Automatic is set to transform recurring payments.

And projects with some banks and SAP Consulting Companies show that the future of finance integration is already being built ‚Äî API by API, event by event, directly into SAP.

References

  • Central Bank of Brazil ‚Äî Pix and Pix Automatic regulatory framework
  • Banco Central do Brasil ‚Äî Open Finance and Pix evolution
  • Santander Brazil ‚Äî Pix innovation initiatives
  • Makevalue ‚Äî SAP integration and banking API projects
  • Industry articles on Pix Automatic and recurring payments (2024‚Äì2025)

entry.title: Re: different e-mail adresses for sending purchase order...

MM-LIV Consignment settlements or ERS credit notes are always sent to the default mail address (Is hard coded) 
The GS Address should be marked as default address

Implement BADI BADI_MM_PO_OC_EMAIL - IF_BADI_MM_PO_OC_EMAIL~CHANGE_RECIPIENTS

DATA lv_smtp_addr TYPE ad_smtpadr.

SELECT SINGLE a~smtp_addr 
    INTO lv_smtp_addr
  FROM adr6 AS a INNER JOIN adrt AS b ON a~addrnumber = b~addrnumber AND
                                                                                    a~persnumber = b~persnumber AND
                                                                                    a~date_from = b~date_from AND
                                                                                    a~consnumber = b~consnumber
                                   INNER JOIN lfa1 AS c ON b~addrnumber = c~adrnr
WHERE c~lifnr = im_nast_entry-parnr AND b~remark = 'BA' AND b~comm_type = 'INT'. 

IF sy-subrc = 0.
    CLEAR cht_to_recipient_list. 
    APPEND lv_smtp_addr TO cht_to_recipient_list.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Leveraging SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026: A Migration Path to SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction

Background

Following SAP‚Äôs announcement of the upcoming SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 release, many customers are seeking clarity on how this new version differs from the existing SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA and what actions they should take today to prepare.

SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 represents the next evolution of SAP‚Äôs governance, risk, and compliance portfolio, offering enhanced capabilities and long-term support. While the new release is not yet available, customers can already take important steps to simplify their current GRC landscape and position themselves for a smoother upgrade when SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 becomes available.

This blog outlines why preparing now on SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA matters, what benefits customers can expect from SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026, and how SAP consulting services can support this journey.

 

Why SAP GRC for S/4HANA Now?

The move to SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA is a preparatory and consolidation step, not something customers should delay until SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 is released.

Today, many customers run SAP GRC components, UI Data Protection, and Assurance & Compliance solutions across multiple systems or instances, sometimes even outside of SAP S/4HANA. Consolidating these capabilities into a single SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA instance enables customers to:

  • Simplify their GRC architecture and reduce operational and technical complexity
  • Be technically ready for a future upgrade to SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026

Importantly, this consolidation effort often requires significant planning and execution time, which is why starting early is critical.

Objectives

The primary goals of this paper are to:

  • Highlight the advantages of migrating to SAP GRC for S/4HANA.
  • Explain how the SAP GRC for S/4HANA version integrates multiple solutions.
  • Introduce SAP consulting services as a comprehensive solution for a seamless migration.

Scope

This blog highlights the benefits of migrating to SAP GRC for S/4HANA, especially for customers using:

  • SAP Access Control
  • SAP Process Control
  • SAP Risk Management
  • SAP Assurance and Compliance applications (Audit Management, Business Integrity Screening, Business Partner Screening, Tax Compliance)
  • UI Data Protection Masking and UI Data Protection Logging

Moving these solutions into a single SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA instance creates a clean and stable foundation for future innovation and upgrades.

Benefits of SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026

Enhanced Compliance and Efficiency

The SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 version introduces upcoming innovations designed to enhance compliance and streamline processes in which some key benefits include:

  • AI Integration: Use of AI for advanced risk detection and reporting.
  • Enhanced User Interface (UI): Improved user experience with a more intuitive interface.
  • Improved Reporting: Enhanced reporting capabilities for better visualization, disclosure and compliance management.

Integrated Solutions

One of the standout features of the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 version is its ability to combine multiple solutions into a unified platform. This includes:

  • GRC Core Solutions: Access Control, Process Control, and Risk Management.
  • Assurance and Compliance Solutions: Audit Management, Business Integrity Screening, and Tax Compliance.
  • UI Data Protection: Masking, and Logging.

By integrating these solutions, organizations can benefit from:

  • Centralized Data Management: A unified platform for comprehensive data management and reporting.
  • Seamless Workflows: Improved coordination between different GRC functions.
  • Reduced Complexity: Simplified deployment and maintenance of GRC solutions.

Migration Strategy

Consulting Services

To ensure a seamless migration, SAP offers comprehensive consulting services. Our expert team can guide you through every step of the process, providing tailored solutions to meet your specific needs. Prepare today and migrate confidently later.

Key services include:

  • Assessment and Planning: Evaluate your current deployment and develop a detailed migration plan.
  • Migration execution: Our consulting team has both tools and expertise to perform wide range of migration tasks, from simplest to the most complex.
  • Technical Support: Provide hands-on technical assistance during the migration.
  • Post-Migration Support: Ensure a smooth transition and address any post-migration issues.

Customized Solutions

SAP's consulting services can be tailored to your organization's unique requirements, ensuring that the migration aligns with your business objectives and technical environment. Our experts will work closely with you to:

  • Optimize Workflows: Streamline GRC processes to improve efficiency.
  • Enhance Compliance: Ensure that your organization meets all regulatory requirements.
  • Maximize ROI: Leverage the full potential of the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 version to drive business value.

Conclusion

Summary

Preparing for SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 starts today. By consolidating on SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA, customers can simplify their GRC landscape, reduce complexity, and significantly lower the risk and effort of a future upgrade. SAP consulting services provide the guidance and expertise needed to make this transition efficient and well-controlled.

Implications

Successful migration to the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 version will enhance your organization's compliance efforts, improve system performance, and ensure long-term support and regulatory compliance. Engaging with SAP's consulting services will make this process efficient and reliable.

Details and Benefits of SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026

  • AI Integration improves risk detection and reporting.
  • Enhanced UI offers a more intuitive user experience.
  • Improved Reporting bolsters visualization and compliance management.
  • Integrated Solutions unify GRC Core and Assurance functions, promoting centralized data management, seamless workflows, and reduced complexity.

Additionally, for a deeper dive into the product management session and a preview of the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 solution, follow this link.

Contact Us

To learn more about the migration to SAP GRC for S/4HANA and engage with our consulting services, please contact us at:

  • Email: sap_dmlt_gce@sap.com

Stay tuned for announcements about upcoming SAP and partner webinars!

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud - How to retrieve currency code...
entry.content:
Hi byd,

Instead of the table, do you have a CDS View you think would work?

In the public cloud, the tables are not exposed, you need to work through CDS View

For example would I_Currency or I_CurrencyStdVH work for you? (I_Currency references the table you mention).

You can review the cds views in the View Browser app.

If so, you can create a custom CDS View based on the CDS View you want to expose. Then expose the Custom CDS View as an ODATA Service.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/e30de6eae4d24d70b65996ac8ff88848.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

 

Thank you
Jerry

entry.title: Re: SAP Business Data Cloud Certification (C_BCBDC): The Ultimate Guide to Passing SAP‚Äôs New AI Scen
entry.content:
Please help me. I studied a lot for this certification, and on my first attempt I failed because I did not finish within two hours. This happened because there were delays and I received messages like ‚Äúmy page has been blocked.‚Äù I was using Microsoft Edge for that first attempt (please do not use this browser). I did not even receive a score just a general explanation of why I probably failed. At first, I thought it was my fault and I blamed myself for not being faster, but it seems the exam stopped almost on the last question. With the delays, it was impossible to finish, and I did not have the option to switch to a new browser or indicate that I was experiencing technical issues. However, I think I should have received a score based on my responses, and I did not.

As I said, I thought it was my fault, so I took the exam again one week later. I used the same browser, and the same problem happened. I decided to open Chrome this time; however, the camera was not working. Still, the AI agent was fine, everything worked well, I was answering the questions and receiving AI feedback, and the conversation was smooth with no delays. The AI agent finished the call with 15 minutes remaining, but again I received no score, just a generic failed message after time was up.


I felt so bad. I thought this time it went well, so I decided to take the exam again that same day in the afternoon. Everything was going well, and I was answering the questions and receiving AI feedback, I felt motivated. With 40 minutes remaining, she said she had to go and only had two more minutes, and she asked the last question. It was about steps, so I checked my notes and then responded. She said, ‚ÄúWell, that was a lot for me,‚Äù asked for my email, and said, ‚ÄúI will send you an email to continue with the remaining questions.‚Äù I thought that was the last question. Then she left with 38 minutes remaining, and the score and feedback kept ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù for those 38 minutes until time was up. Again, I received a failed message and no score, just like the first two exams.


I lost my attempts, and this is not fair. Please help. I created a case with SAP yesterday, but I have not received a response yet. üòû

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: 2026 starts with SAP Champions posts, AI tips and survey to give your opinion!
entry.content:
Happy New Year!  

Our Community Voice is back, and we are more than happy to be present for our SAP Community in 2026. We hope our members got to enjoy some relaxing and festive times and that you are feeling rested and prepared to start this year with the right attitude. 2026 is going to be full of amazing moments and opportunities to keep learning, connecting, and growing our community all over the world. 

To start the year right, we collected some of the great highlights that have already been happening in the first two weeks of January. Very insightful blog posts about new features and recommendations for the best use of SAP technologies, a nice opportunity to explore what is new on our platform, and a look at how our SAP Mentors and Champions have been collaborating within the SAP Community, plus all the great events coming this year! 

Let‚Äôs dive in! 

Featured Blog Posts 

SAP Integration Suite New Features Released at the End of 2025 

In Q4 of 2025, SAP Integration Suite delivered great new features, such as AI-powered recommendations that simplify troubleshooting and streamlined connectivity with top platforms like Amazon Kinesis and Box. SAP¬¥s Maiara Ellwanger recently posted a blog post covering the details of these innovations, along with information on new dataspace integration packages, data center availability in new locations, event-driven integrations, B2B interchanges in Trading Partner Management, and new features in Process Integration. Make sure to check out her blog post, as it includes all the details you need to boost your operational efficiency. 

Read Maiara Ellwanger Blog Post here 

Synchronizing BTP Accounts into SAP LeanIX 

One of the main pillars of IT landscape expansion is maintaining transparency and governance. It is important not only to know how systems are connected, but also to understand what exists, why it exists, who owns it, and how it fits into the overall enterprise architecture. SAP Champion Punith Oswal, explains in his latest blog post how LeanIX plays a crucial role with Enterprise Architecture Management, considering that LeanIX focuses heavily on‚ÄØdata-driven architecture decisions, ensuring that architecture is not just diagrams, but‚ÄØliving documentation. If you want to have a full explanation on how the SAP BTP accounts works in LeanIX and the details on the process (including very helpful images, to make your life even easier finding the configurations), this content is a must read.  

Read Punith Oswall Blog Post here 

Tips on How to Start 2026 with SAP¬¥s AI offer 

Generative AI is more omnipresent than ever in daily lives, and according to SAP¬¥s Leo Irudayam the key to successful AI adoption is a useful case, with the right technology and people. In his blog post, he makes AI tools tangible and understandable by sketching an AI-assisted process of vehicle onboarding, showing how it can be automated by leveraging different AI tools offered by SAP within the Business AI portfolio. Leo also explores SAP¬¥s own foundational model RPT-1 and agentic tasks with Joule Studio. He concludes with a reminder that SAP Document AI is a leader in document processing with inbound and outbound channels, and SAP AI Core a powerful AI orchestration service at low costs each. 

Read Leo Irudayam Blog Post here 

Different approach: UI5 Library Use on BTP by Bundling Libraries at Build Time 

SAP Champion Mio Yasutake published a great blog post presenting valuable tools for simplifying UI5 Library use on BTP, considering two different approaches (with and without CDM) and the benefits and limitations of deploying libraries independently. The highlight of her post is an alternative approach: Bundling the Library at Build time. She explains that the main advantage of this approach are the simpler application configuration and the removal of dependencies on resources defined by the library, such as destinations or HTML5 app host service instances. Mio provides a detailed step-by-step guide with images and all the necessary code. We highly recommend checking it out! 

Read here Mio Yasutake Blog Post here 

Community News 

Tell us what you think and win a virtual meet and greet with Josh Bentley 

We want to hear what you think! SAP Community Advocate Mynyna Chau, recently opened a survey (click here to participate), so our Community Team knows your thoughts, needs and preferences. This is our way to tailor our future community initiatives accordingly, but also because we believe that your input makes a difference. The survey takes just a few minutes of your time and can be completed from your smartphone or computer. Once the survey concludes, we will carefully analyze the results and share a report summary with you.  

And as a token of our appreciation, helping us spread the word enters you into a draw to win a virtual meet & greet with Josh Bentley, head of SAP Community! All you need to do is share the survey link / QR-Code in your social media and comment on Mynyna¬¥s Blog Post here with a link to your social media post that shows how you helped spread the word.‚ÄØ 

Hobbies Series: Passion for Writing

The holiday season can be a wonderful opportunity to relax and be available for activities that are often left behind during normal routines. These breaks also allow us to discover hobbies that keep our minds engaged with things we love. At the beginning of this month, SAP Community members shared insights into their favorite activities as part of our Hobbies Series. SAP¬¥s Hakan Haslaman wrote about his passion for writing (blog post here), describing it to shape his experiences and thoughts, whether from everyday life or situations far outside his comfort zone. He shared valuable insights into writing and the topics he enjoys most. He concludes by explaining that in his work in Support, two things are constant: complexity and humanity. And writing and coaching helps him to connect both.  

Events 

Reminder of SAP ALM Summit North America 2026 

As we have previously mentioned before, we would like to remind everyone about the upcoming SAP ALM Summit North America 2026. This event is the chance to boost your ALM value by learning from real-life customer experiences. Expand your knowledge through hands-on labs and attending expert-led sessions.‚ÄØ Some of the amazing speakers that will be presenting at the event are Tim Steuer - VP Customer Communications & Relations SAP SE, S√∂ren Ruder-‚ÄØHead of Customer Experience & Solutions (CXS)‚ÄØSAP SE, Joshua Greenbaum-‚ÄØPrincipal of Enterprise Applications Consulting EAC and Todd Crandall-‚ÄØHead of Customer Services & Delivery SAP North America. Make sure to register for the event here:‚ÄØSAP ALM Summit NA 2026.‚ÄØ 

This year Upcoming Events  

Time flies, and we are already in the middle of January 2026. It is time to organize yourself and book all the great events you cannot miss this year. Check out the list below to see the events already scheduled for 2026:‚ÄØ 

  • 20 of January: SAP CodeJam -‚ÄØBuild AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Bielefeld, Germa...‚ÄØ 
  • 21 of January: SAP CodeJam‚ÄØ-‚ÄØGetting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core ( Hyderabad, India )‚ÄØ 
  • 22 of January: SAP CodeJam ABAP: SAP BTP, ABAP Environment & RAP ( Hyderabad, India )‚ÄØ 
  • 23 of January:‚ÄØSAP Stammtisch Wroclaw - January Edition! (Registration is closed)‚ÄØ 
  • 29 of January:‚ÄØSAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India)‚ÄØ 
  • 09 of February:‚ÄØBuild AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Pune, India)‚ÄØ 
  • 26 of February:‚ÄØ‚ÄØBuild AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Gent, Belgium)‚ÄØ 
  • 14 of March: SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026 ‚Äì Brasil‚ÄØ 
  • 17 of March:‚ÄØSAP TALK WOMEN CWB 2026- Curitiba, Brasil‚ÄØ 
  • 14 - 16 of April: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026- Pennsylvania, United States 
  • 26 of September: SAP Inside Track Porto 2026 - Portugal‚ÄØ 
  • 31 of October: SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026- Brasil‚ÄØ‚ÄØ

entry.title: Re: eInvoicing Direct Debit SEPA Mandate #COE#SW01
entry.content:
This is the reply I got from the SAP ticket.

We would like to confirm that in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the behavior you are is expected and system-standard.

When a Billing Document (Debit Memo) is created using the Billing Document Request Excel upload, the SEPA Mandate Reference is not populated. This is because the Excel upload process creates billing documents without using the Sales and Distribution (SD) document flow, and therefore SD copy control logic is not executed. The SEPA Mandate Reference is derived only when billing documents are created from SD documents such as Sales Orders or Contracts.

As a result:

  • The standard Excel upload template does not include a field for SEPA Mandate Reference
  • The system has no source document from which to derive the mandate
  • The mandate reference therefore remains empty and is not passed to the Belgium e-invoice

This is a current functional limitation in S/4HANA Public Cloud, not a tenant-specific restriction.

When billing documents are created via:

  • Sales Order ‚Üí Billing, or
  • Contract ‚Üí Billing

the SEPA Mandate Reference is correctly derived and passed through to the Belgium e-invoice (Peppol XML).

For Belgium SEPA Direct Debit scenarios, SAP recommends using SD-based billing processes to ensure full SEPA and e-invoicing compliance. Upload-based billing (Excel Billing Document Requests) should be avoided for customers requiring SEPA mandates.

SAP is aware of this functional gap. Therefore, now we redirect this incident to a dedicated team and request for a possible support and workaround. 

Thank you for your patience and regards,
EU Peppol Development Team

entry.title: Re: How to bring your ABAP custom code to SAP BTP ABAP Environment
entry.content:
Hi David @dnguyen_31 ,

the recommended approach ("how") is as described in this blog. I would recommend to check this add-on for cloud readiness like described here: https://blogs.sap.com/2018/10/02/how-to-check-your-custom-abap-code-for-sap-cloud-platform-abap-environment/ and see how many issues you get and if it would be manageble to resolve them without having to reimplement the whole add-on code. Generally, if the add-on tightly coupled with the SAP IS-U component, it is not recommendable to outsource it to BTP ABAP environment (e.g. if the data of SAP IS-U is changed jointly, or frequent SQL access to SAP IS-U is used, reading high data volume from SAP IS-U tables, calling many SAP IS-U APIs which are not publicly released....).

Kind Regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Partner Kickoff 2026: Product direction, 2026 priorities, and how we will activate together
entry.content:
We are excited to kick off 2026 with a shared view of where we are headed and how we will activate together. The Partner Kickoff 2026 will cover product direction, 2026 priorities, and the partner engagement plan so you can align your teams and plan your year.

Partner Kickoff 2026 is a virtual kickoff replacing the 2025 Partner Summits. It is designed to give partners a consistent view of what is coming and how we will work together across the year, including key engagement opportunities across regions.

What you will get

This kickoff is built to be practical and actionable. You can expect:

  • 2026 priorities and focus areas, including what we are driving and how it connects to partner growth
  • Product strategy and direction, including what is coming and how to align your offerings and messaging
  • Partner engagement plan and key dates, including where to plug in across regions and how to prioritize your calendar
  • Clear next steps so you know what to do after the kickoff and how to keep teams aligned

Who should attend

This kickoff is designed for leaders and teams responsible for growth and readiness, including:

  • Partner and alliance leaders
  • Sales and pre-sales leaders
  • Marketing and enablement leads

Register

Join us on Jan 21 to align on the strategy, product direction, and engagement plan for 2026.
